Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in determining that allegations 3 to 6 were out of time and the Applicant's reasons for delay insufficient
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's delay in filing complaint, personal decisions, alternate recourse pursued
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanation for delay deemed insufficient
Legal_Rule: Complaints must be filed within one year unless extended by the Commission
Grounds_for_Claim: Discrimination by RCMP leading to dismissal
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached – complaint dismissed on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of dismissal (December 2001), contact with Commission (March 2002), official filing date (October 2003)
Applicant_Challenge: Commission’s refusal to accept late complaint
Legal_Rule_Source: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities, applied under patent unreasonableness standard
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but Commission upheld procedural timeline
Outcome: Complaint not heard due to being out of time
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative review followed by judicial review
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court
Legal_Provision_Cited: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Time-barred complaint, insufficient justification for delay
Applicable_Process: Filing of discrimination complaint, administrative review, judicial review
Governing_Rule: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
